narrative.title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan

question.text: Types and amount of scientific data expected to be generated in the project

json.answer:
We anticipate generating a large volume of scientific data, including:

* Tabular demographic/clinical data for 220 participants
* Multi-modal MRI imaging files (structural MRI, fMRI, and 1H fMRS) for each participant

The estimated total size of the dataset is approximately 10-15 TB.

question.text: Scientific data that will be preserved and shared, and the rationale for doing so

json.answer: All scientific data collected in this project will be preserved and shared to facilitate further research and collaboration. The sharing of de-identified demographic, clinical, and MRI imaging data will enable other researchers to replicate our findings, validate new methods, and explore new hypotheses.

question.text: Metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation

json.answer:
The following metadata and associated documentation will be made accessible:

* Data dictionaries
* Study protocols
* README files
* Scan parameters for MRI images

These metadata and documentation will facilitate interpretation of the scientific data and provide context for the research findings.

section.title: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

question.text: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

json.answer:
----------------------------------------------

No specialized tools or software are required to access or manipulate shared scientific data. All data will be provided in standard formats (e.g., CSV, NIfTI), which can be easily imported into various analysis platforms.

---------------------

We will apply the following common data standards to ensure interoperability of datasets and resources:

* DICOM for MRI images
* csv and JSON for tabular data

These data standards are widely adopted in the field of biomedical research, ensuring that our data can be easily shared and integrated with other datasets.

section.title: Element 4: Data Preservation, Access, and Associated Timelines

question.text: Repository where scientific data and metadata will be archived

json.answer: The dataset will be preserved and shared through the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) Data Archive (NDA). This repository is specifically designed for sharing sensitive research data related to mental health.

question.text: How scientific data will be findable and identifiable

json.answer: Each dataset will be assigned a persistent unique identifier, enabling easy retrieval and citation. The NDA's search function will allow users to locate datasets based on keywords, study IDs, or participant demographics.

question.text: When and how long the scientific data will be made available

json.answer: The data will be made available no later than 12 months after the end of the project performance period, which is in accordance with NIH guidelines. The dataset will remain accessible for a minimum of 5 years from the date of initial availability.

section.title: Element 5: Access, Distribution, or Reuse Considerations

question.text: Factors affecting subsequent access, distribution, or reuse of scientific data

json.answer: Consent forms signed by participants explicitly permit broad sharing and reuse of their de-identified data. We anticipate no limitations on data sharing due to informed consent restrictions.

question.text: Whether access to scientific data will be controlled

json.answer: Access to the dataset will not be controlled. The NDA allows direct download of datasets, ensuring that users can easily retrieve the data for analysis or further research.

question.text: Protections for privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants

json.answer: The dataset is de-identified and anonymized, with no direct linkages to individual identities. We have implemented robust measures to protect participant privacy and confidentiality, including secure storage and access controls.

section.title: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

question.text: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

json.answer:
---------------------------------------------------

To ensure compliance with this Plan, our institution will assign a senior investigator as the Data Manager, responsible for monitoring data sharing activities and resolving any issues that may arise. The Data Manager will report to the Principal Investigator on a quarterly basis to confirm data sharing progress.

Frequency of oversight: Quarterly

By whom at your institution: Senior Investigator (Data Manager)

This Data Management and Sharing Plan outlines our commitment to preserving and sharing high-quality, open-access scientific data generated in this project.
